title.narrative: Share-Net International

description.narrative:
Share-Net International (SNI), the knowledge platform on sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), combines the expertise and strengths of development organisations, Southern partners and key international actors in the field of SRHR to achieve the SRHR and HIV related Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Membership includes universities, knowledge institutes, development organisations, civil society organisations, media outlets, students and individual experts in the field of SRHR. The Platform encompasses national knowledge networks in four countries: Bangladesh, Burundi, Jordan and the Netherlands. These networks serve as conduits for situation assessments, defining research priorities, facilitating research participation by country institutions and hosting the local knowledge base/platform. They stimulate the participation of key international partners and regional and national SRHR actors. SNI aims to strengthen linkages between research, policy and practice through sharing, generating, translating and promoting the use of knowledge for the development of better policies and practices in SRHR.
The main services of SNI and its country hubs include • Meetings, discussions, (de-)briefings: SNI organises a diverse range of meetings focused around relevant topics or give (de-)briefings of global happenings. Furthermore, SNI coordinates activities planned or initiated by members. • Communities of Practice are at the heart of SNI and operate in each country hub, are context specific and create common ground for members while engaging in dialogues and activities. Under this networking outcome, SNI acts as a matchmaker; promoting interactions between the members of the CoPs and encouraging them to share knowledge which facilitates learning and ultimately, using this knowledge to improve policy and practice. • Share-Net International Rapid Improvement Model promotes knowledge exchange between the country hubs, aiming to o Improve understanding of which knowledge translation strategies contribute to change in SRHR policy or practice in the specific context of each country hub. o Develop the capacity of the participating staff in the hubs for knowledge management and brokering o Facilitate learning, collaboration and exchange between country hubs. • SNI Co-Creation Conference aims at translating knowledge into products that allow SNI members and other participants to improve policy and practice on selected SRHR themes. Next to the development of these knowledge products, the Co-Creation Conference promotes uptake of knowledge in SRHR programmes, policies and practice through the development and presentation of narrative reviews and evidence briefs on the selected topics. • Online activities (website, newsletters) share relevant knowledge and resources on SRHR with the wider public making SRHR information accessible to all.

participating-org.narrative: Association des Editeurs du Magazine Jimbere

sector.narrative: Share-Net International (SNI), the knowledge platform on sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), combines the expertise and strengths of development organisations, Southern partners and key international actors in the field of SRHR to achieve the SRHR and HIV related Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Membership includes universities, knowledge institutes, development organisations, civil society organisations, media outlets, students and individual experts in the field of SRHR. The Platform encompasses national knowledge networks in four countries: Bangladesh, Burundi, Jordan and the Netherlands. These networks serve as conduits for situation assessments, defining research priorities, facilitating research participation by country institutions and hosting the local knowledge base/platform. They stimulate the participation of key international partners and regional and national SRHR actors. SNI aims to strengthen linkages between research, policy and practice through sharing, generating, translating and promoting the use of knowledge for the development of better policies and practices in SRHR.

title.narrative: The network of Share-Net country hubs is connected and promotes the jointly developed SRHR knowledge agenda
Number of training/capacity buiilding sessions for SN country hubs

comment.narrative: We planned to follow 1 French training

One French training and capacity building sessions on institutional fundraising; working online and proposal writing; communication & networking; power and equity in global development; SHIRIM methodology; strategies for sustainability. These capacity building sessions were initially not planned.

title.narrative: Financial management of the Share-Net knowledge platform
Number of proposals submitted to seeking funds

description.narrative: To extent to which the financial execution is in line with financial planning

comment.narrative: In line with diversifying our funding we commit to submit 1 proposal for seeking funds

Nuffic: In 2021, KIT/Share-Net received funding through the TMT+ Ensemble: Linking and learning on SRHR in a digital era. The total project budget equals 400.000. Around 80.000 euros of which went to a training on the concept and management of CoPs and the set-up and activity budget of this CoP in the Sahel (Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger and Bénin). The training was implemented by Charlotte van Tuijl and Olivier Makambira.

Number of research products prepared

description.narrative: Number and kind of knowledge that has been generated through SNI and the country hubs

comment.narrative: An International Position Paper on Meaningful Youth Participation and Youth Empowerment and a toolkit on How to set up a community of practice on SRHR were created.

title.narrative: Addressing priority knowledge gaps through research and further analysis and synthesis of existing data
Number of small grants rewarded

description.narrative: Number and kind of knowledge that has been generated through SNI and the country hubs

comment.narrative: We budgeted to award 14 small grants of 10 000 euros.

In total, 22 small grants were awarded in 2021 of which 14 regular small grants (1 in Jordan, 1 in Ukraine, 1 in Nigeria, 1 in Malawi, 1 in Egypt, 3 in Burundi, 3 in Bangladesh, 3 in Netherlands) and seven grants were awarded as a result of the Co-Creation Conference.

title.narrative: Networking at national (CoP) and international level (partners)
Number of newly registered members (per sector)

description.narrative: Efforts SN has made to broaden its network

comment.narrative: Based on growth in 2020, we plan to have 30 new members in 2021
12 new individual members and 32 new organisational members. Most new organisational members are relatively small NGO’s from East or West Africa.

title.narrative: Networking at national (CoP) and international level (partners)
Number of new (inter)national partnerships established

description.narrative: Efforts SN has made to broaden its network

comment.narrative: Besides the partnerships with the 3 new host organisations (which are not counted as partnerships here) we have also strengthened collaboration with abortion group, and the climate change coalition led by WD. We also started conversations with strategic members, e.g. The Menstrual Health Hub, with whom we plan fundraising activities together.

title.narrative: Networking at national (CoP) and international level (partners)
Number of active Communities of Practice

description.narrative: Number of CoPs that have been established and their respective topics

comment.narrative: We plan to set up 2 international CoPs in 2021 on gender-based violence and SRHR for adolescents and youth

In 2021, there was one international CoP on COVID-19 SRHR and Gender Equality. This iCoP was only active in Q1 of 2021 with the rounding up of their activities and the dissemination meetings which took place in February and March 2021.

description.narrative: Efforts SN has made to broaden its network

comment.narrative:
20 new organizational members (all NGOs/CSOs) of which two alliances made up from multiple organisations, notably AYOSA and ESA Youth 2030. 7 individual members of which 1 clinician, 2 consultants, 3 individuals working at NGOs and 1 public health specialist. 20 new organizational members (all NGOs/CSOs) of which two alliances made up from multiple organisations, notably AYOSA and ESA Youth 2030. 7 individual members of which 1 clinician, 2 consultants, 3 individuals working at NGOs and 1 public health specialist. 20 new organizational members (all NGOs/CSOs) of which two alliances made up from multiple organisations, notably AYOSA and ESA Youth 2030. 7 individual members of which 1 clinician, 2 consultants, 3 individuals working at NGOs and 1 public health specialist. 20 new organizational members (all NGOs/CSOs) of which two alliances made up from multiple organisations, notably AYOSA and ESA Youth 2030. 7 individual members of which 1 clinician, 2 consultants, 3 individuals working at NGOs and 1 public health specialist. 20 new organizational members (all NGOs/CSOs) of which two alliances made up from multiple organisations, notably AYOSA and ESA Youth 2030. 7 individual members of which 1 clinician, 2 consultants, 3 individuals working at NGOs and 1 public health specialist.

We organised a session in collaboration with CREA during the Annual Business Meeting in 2021 and organised 3 international sessions during the Linking Research Policy and Practice conference: Maternal and Menstrual Health

title.narrative: Promotion of use of knowledge products and formats by policy makers and practitioners

description.narrative: Number and kind of knowledge that has been promoted for use

comment.narrative: We commit to organising one thematic session a year

We organised a session in collaboration with CREA during the Annual Business Meeting in 2021 and organised 3 international sessions during the Linking Research Policy and Practice conference: Maternal and Menstrual Health; SRHR and education; underexposed perspectives.

This was not assessed in 2021 because there were no active CoPs for the majority of the year.

title.narrative: Policy makers
practitioners and researchers have better access to SRHR information and knowledge
